thread.title: North East business confidence rebounds to 18-month high after Brexit vote

author: Jonathon Manning
title: North East business confidence rebounds to 18-month high after Brexit vote
text:
Leigh Taylor, area director, SME Banking in the North East, at Lloyds Bank Commercial Banking (Photo: Publicity Pic)   
Business confidence across North East businesses has rebounded to an 18-month high following the Brexit vote, new research has shown. 
Firms right across the region said they expected sales, orders and profits to grow over the next six months, according to the Business in Britain report from Lloyds Bank, based on data gathered after the snap election had been called. 
The confidence index increased to 33%, up from January’s figure of 22%, suggesting rising optimism among businesses, despite enduring increasing challenges in hiring skilled and unskilled labour. 
Leigh Taylor, regional director for SME in the North East at Lloyds, said: “Overall confidence in the North East has increased since our last survey in January. 
“The fact that this has happened despite the political uncertainty from a snap election is a positive sign for underlying confidence in the region.” 
The North East ranked second highest on the list in terms of business confidence, coming in behind Wales with 34%. 
Despite the region’s optimistic outlook the number of firms struggling to recruited skilled staff rose to a ten-year high of 49%. The Union flag and the EU flag flying (Photo: PA) 
Mr Taylor added: “Despite hurdles in recruiting both skilled and unskilled labour, North East businesses also anticipate sales, profits, and staffing levels to rise. 
“The outlook for the external environment remains mixed, with details of Britain’s exit from the EU still to come but businesses have been working within those parameters for a while now. Read More NFU demands action as seasonal worker numbers plummet by 17% during key harvest month 
“For the moment, North East businesses are taking this in their stride until there is a clearer sense of what it will mean for them in the short and medium term.” 
While confidence from North East business leaders is on the up, further research suggests that SMEs are having a tough time. 
Fresh research from challenger bank CYBG found that the health of UK SMEs has fallen to its lowest level in three years. 
The bank’s Health Check Index suggested SMEs in the North East faced a challenging business and economic environment in the opening quarter of 2017, highlighted by the index falling from 53.9 in Q4 2016 to 48.9, although the region remained above the 2016 average. 
Topping off the bad news for small businesses was a 6% rise in the number of UK business insolvencies that occurred during the quarter. Headline figures were also hampered by slower revenue growth and rising spare capacity. 
David Duffy, CEO at CYBG, said: “Never forget, small and medium-sized businesses are the absolute engine room of the British economy, and their future prospects are going to be ever more critical in a post-Brexit world, where we are dependent on a stronger and more competitive domestic economy. 
“It is vital that we understand how SMEs are performing.” Like us on Facebook
